questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following hormones is not secreted by the ovary?
questions.explanation:
Gonadotropins (FSH, LH) are not secreted by the ovary. They are secreted by the anterior 
pituitary. Ovaries secrete estrogen, progesterone, and inhibin B.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 30-year-old lady has regular, infrequent menstrual cycles occurring at an interval of 35-36 
days. What is the usual timing of ovulation in this lady?
questions.explanation:
Ovulation occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length. If we calculate the day of menstruation from the beginning of the cycle, in a 28-day cycle, 
ovulation occurs on day 14 and in a 35-day cycle, ovulation will occur on day 22. 791 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: LH surge leads to ovulation. Ovulation does not occur before LH surge. Option C: The ruptured ovarian follicle (after ovulation) is converted into corpus luteum. 
Ovulation does not occur after corpus luteal maturation. Option D: Ovulation will occur 14 days before menstruation, i.e. on day 22 of a 35-day cycle. It 
does not occur 22 days before menstruation.

questions.question: Question 3: The corpus luteum starts regressing after how many days post ovulation?
questions.explanation:
The human corpus luteum starts regressing ~10 days after ovulation. Ovulation occurs on day 14, and the day corpus luteum begins to regress on day 25 of the 
menstrual cycle. Therefore, Days after ovulation when corpus luteum starts regressing = 25-14 = 11 days The human corpus luteum is programmed to live for 14 days, plus or minus 2 days (corpus luteum 
of menstruation). Figure Events of the menstrual cycle:

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is not seen in humans?
questions.explanation:
Estrous cycle is not seen in humans. Mammals other than primates do not menstruate, and their sexual cycle is called an estrous cycle. 
It is named for the conspicuous period of “heat” (estrus) at the time of ovulation, normally the 
only time during which the sexual interest of the female is aroused. 792 
Sold by @itachibot In spontaneously ovulating species with estrous cycles, such as the rat, no episodic vaginal 
bleeding occurs, but the underlying endocrine events are essentially the same as those in the 
menstrual cycle. In other species, ovulation is induced by copulation (reflex ovulation).

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is the dominant hormone in the luteal phase?
questions.explanation:
• Progesterone is the dominant hormone during the luteal phase. • The corpus luteum in the non-pregnant woman secretes large quantities of progesterone and a 
small amount of estrogen, as well as inhibin. • In terms of ovarian function, the menstrual cycle may be divided into two phases approximately 
equal in length and separated by ovulation (Figure): • The follicular phase, during which a mature follicle and secondary oocyte develop; and • The luteal phase begins after ovulation and lasts until the death of the corpus luteum. Follicular phase (days 0–14) • A primordial follicle develops to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles. • LH and FSH receptors are up-regulated in theca and granulosa cells. • Estradiol levels increase and cause proliferation of the uterus. • FSH and LH levels are suppressed by the negative feedback effect of estradiol on the anterior 
pituitary. • Progesterone levels are low. Ovulation (day 14) • Occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length. Thus, in a 28-day cycle, ovulation 
occurs on day 14; in a 35-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 22. 793 
Sold by @itachibot • A burst of estradiol synthesis at the end of the follicular phase has a positive feedback effect on 
the secretion of FSH and LH (LH surge). • Ovulation occurs as a result of the estrogen-induced LH surge. • Estrogen levels decrease just after ovulation (but rise again during the luteal phase). • Cervical mucus increases in quantity; it becomes less viscous and more penetrable by sperm. Luteal phase (days 14–28) • The corpus luteum begins to develop, and it synthesizes estrogen and progesterone. Vascularity 
and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for receipt of a fertilized egg. • Basal body temperature increases because of the effect of progesterone on the hypothalamic 
thermoregulatory center. • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a 
result, estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly. Menses (days 0–4) • The endometrium is sloughed because of the abrupt withdrawal of estradiol and progesterone 794 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following hormones is responsible for the maintenance of endometrial thickness 
in the post-ovulatory phase?
questions.explanation:
Progesterone is mainly responsible for the maintenance of endometrial thickness in the 
post-ovulatory phase. The menstrual cycle consists of three phases: the menstrual phase, the proliferative phase, and the 
secretory, or progestational, phase Menstrual phase: This phase is characterized by the discharge of blood and endometrial debris 
from the vagina. • It coincides with the end of the ovarian luteal phase and onset of a new follicular phase. • Withdrawal of progesterone on the degeneration of the corpus luteum (CL) leads simultaneously 
to sloughing of the endometrium (menstruation) and development of new follicles in the ovary 
under the influence of rising gonadotropic hormone levels Proliferative Phase: Thus, menstrual flow ceases, and the proliferative phase of the uterine cycle 
begins concurrently with the last portion of the ovarian follicular phase. • When the menstrual flow ceases, a thin endometrial layer less than 1-mm thick remains. 
Estrogen stimulates proliferation of epithelial cells, glands, and blood vessels in the endometrium, 
increasing this lining to a thickness of 3 to 5 mm. • The estrogen-dominant proliferative phase lasts from the end of menstruation to ovulation. Peak 
estrogen levels trigger the luteinizing hormone (LH) surge responsible for ovulation. Secretory or Progestational Phase: After ovulation, when a new corpus luteum is formed, the 
uterus enters the secretory, or progestational, phase, which coincides in time with the ovarian 
luteal phase. The corpus luteum secretes large amounts of progesterone and estrogen. 
Progesterone converts the thickened, estrogen-primed endometrium to a richly vascularized, 
glycogen-filled tissue. • This period is called either the secretory phase, because the endometrial glands are actively 
secreting glycogen into the uterine lumen for early nourishment of a developing embryo before it 795 
Sold by @itachibot implants, or the progestational (“before pregnancy”) phase, referring to the development of a lush 
endometrial lining capable of supporting an early embryo after implantation. • If fertilization and implantation do not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates and a new 
follicular phase and menstrual phase begin again.

questions.question:
Question 7: A couple is planning to conceive by artificial intrauterine insemination (IUI). In order to 
ensure optimal timing for intrauterine transfer of husband sperm, the wife is advised to use a 
home-based ovulation predictor kit. Detecting which of the following hormones in urine is the 
purpose of this kit?
questions.explanation:
Detection of an increased LH level in urine will be performed by this ovulation predictor kit. The most important physiological marker of imminent ovulation is luteinizing hormone (LH) 
surge, which is characterized by an increased level of LH in serum and urine. A peak level of 75 
ng/mL of LH in serum is required for ovulation. LH surge occurs 24-36 hours before ovulation. 
LH peak lasts 24 hours. LH surge causes the following: • Completion of meiosis of ovum • Ovulation • Development of corpus luteum

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following best explains the mechanism behind an increase in LH secretion just 
before ovulation ?
questions.explanation:
Increased luteinizing hormone (LH) secretion just before ovulation is due to positive feedback by 
estrogen. 796 
Sold by @itachibot Phases

questions.question: Question 10: Corpus luteum of pregnancy is maintained by
questions.explanation:
Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG) causes persistence of the corpus luteum and prevents 
menstruation in pregnancy. The fate of the corpus luteum • If the ovum is not fertilized, about 2 days before the end of the monthly cycle, the corpus luteum 
in the ovary involutes • If fertilization occurs, under the influence of human chorionic gonadotropin, the corpus luteum 
in the mother’s ovary grows to about twice its initial size by a month or so after pregnancy begins • The corpus luteum secretes estrogens and progesterone and maintains the decidual nature of the 
uterine endometrium, which is necessary for the early development of the fetus • The corpus luteum of pregnancy involutes slowly after the 13th to 17th week of gestation. After 
that time, the placenta secretes sufficient quantities of progesterone and estrogens to maintain 
pregnancy for the remainder of the gestation period

questions.question: Question 11: FSH receptor is present in
questions.explanation:
• Granulosa cells express the FSH receptor. • Theca interna cells express LH receptor. Theca interna cells have many LH receptors. LH acts via cAMP to increase conversion of 
cholesterol to androstenedione. The theca interna cells supply androstenedione to the granulosa 
cells. The granulosa cells make estradiol when provided with androgens. Granulosa cells have many FSH receptors. FSH facilitates their secretion of estradiol by acting via 
cAMP to increase their aromatase activity. Mature granulosa cells also acquire LH receptors, and 
LH also stimulates estradiol production.

questions.question:
Question 12: 785 
Sold by @itachibot A 30-year-old lady is using the basal body temperature method for contraception. She takes 
note of a rise in her body temperature for abstinence during the fertile period. The increase in 
basal body temperature in the mid-luteal phase is due to which of the following hormones?
questions.explanation:
797 
Sold by @itachibot An increase in basal body temperature in the mid-luteal phase is due to the effect of progesterone 
on the hypothalamic thermoregulatory centre. Immediately after ovulation, corpus luteum is formed, which secretes progesterone in preparation 
of the body for potential pregnancy during that cycle. This progesterone acts on the hypothalamus 
and increases basal body temperature. Charting the daily basal body temperature will show an 
increase of approximately 0.5 to 1 degrees fahrenheit shortly after ovulation. Since the rise in basal body temperature coincides with ovulation, abstaining from sexual 
intercourse until at least 3 days after the woman’s temperature has risen above her regular 
temperature significantly lowers the chance of pregnancy. Alternatively, using barrier 
methods (e.g. condom, diaphragm) during this time will prevent pregnancy. However several factors (e.g fever, sleep deprivation etc.) that change the basal body temperature, 
can affect the efficacy and reliability of this method.

questions.question:
Question 13: A blood sample is drawn on day 20 of the menstrual cycle of a young woman undergoing 
evaluation for irregular menstruation. Serum level of which of the following hormones help in 
assessing whether her cycle was ovulatory or not?
questions.explanation:
Whether her cycle was ovulatory or not can be validly assessed by the reported serum level of 
progesterone. Day 20 usually corresponds to the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. In case of anovulatory 
cycles, no corpus luteum will be formed and so progesterone levels will be low. Hence 
progesterone levels are valuable to predict if the cycles were ovulatory or not.

questions.question: Question 14: Secretion of estrogen is maximum
questions.explanation:
• Estrogen comes from the ovary, and two peaks of secretion occur one just before ovulation and 
one during the mid-luteal phase. • After menopause, estrogen secretion declines to low levels. 798 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following hormones inhibit FSH and LH secretion in the luteal phase?
questions.explanation:
Estrogen inhibits FSH and LH secretion in the luteal phase. Feedback regulation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis Luteal phase: the corpus luteum secretes large quantities of progesterone and estrogen. They exert 
a negative feedback effect on the anterior pituitary gland causing the suppression of both FSH and 
LH secretion. Preovulatory period: The high level of estrogens at this time (or the beginning of progesterone 
secretion by the follicles) causes a positive feedback stimulatory effect on the anterior pituitary 
leading to a surge of LH and to a lesser extent, FSH. Follicular phase: secretion of estrogen, progesterone from the corpus luteum decreases which 
leads to loss of negative feedback effect of these hormones on the anterior pituitary. Therefore, 
pituitary secretion of FSH begins to increase again, as much as twofold. LH secretion increases 
slightly as well. GnRH stimulates FSH and LH secretion. Growth hormone and IGF may cause an increase in FSH 
and LH levels.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following statement can be regarded as primary action of inhibin?
questions.explanation:
The inhibins inhibit FSH secretion by the gonadotrophs of the anterior pituitary (hence the name 
inhibin) in a classic negative feedback arrangement.

questions.question: Question 17: Inhibin B is secreted by
questions.explanation:
The inhibins are produced by the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle, as well as other tissues, 
including the pituitary, the brain, the adrenal gland, the kidney, the bone marrow, the corpus 
luteum, and the placenta. Inhibin A is produced by the corpus luteum whereas inhibin B is mainly 
produced by granulosa cells of the follicle FSH specifically stimulates the granulosa cells to produce inhibins. Just before ovulation, after the granulosa cells acquire LH receptors, LH also stimulates the 
production of inhibin by granulosa cells.

questions.question: Question 18: Source of progesterone during normal menstrual cycle
questions.explanation:
The source of progesterone during the normal menstrual cycle is corpus luteum. Progesterone is also secreted by the placenta, and the ovarian follicle (in small amounts). 799 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is the source of estrogen?
questions.explanation:
Estrogen are secreted primarily by the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicles, the corpus luteum, 
and the placenta .

questions.question:
Question 20: 787 
Sold by @itachibot Regarding the two-cell—two-gonadotropin hypothesis which of the following is true?

options.a: FSH and LH inhibits the release of estrogen and progesterone
options.b: FSH acts on granulosa cells and LH on theca cells
options.c: FSH stimulates estrogen while LH inhibits estrogen
options.d: FSH feedback inhibits hypothalamus while LH feedback inhibits pituitary

questions.explanation:
The two-cell—two-gonadotropin hypothesis: • Estradiol synthesis requires the contribution of two distinct cell types: • The theca and granulosa cells within the follicle and • The theca-lutein and granulosa lutein cells within the corpus luteum • The follicular theca cells, under the control of LH, produce androgens that diffuse to the 
follicular granulosa cells, where they are converted to estrogens via an FSH-supported 
aromatization reaction. The granulosa cells cannot convert progesterone to androstenedione 
because of the lack of the enzyme 17 -hydroxylase.

questions.question: Question 21: Regarding the action of progesterone which of the following is true?

options.a: Increases sensitivity of uterus to oxytocin
options.d: Causes marked proliferative changes in uterus

questions.explanation:
Progesterone inhibits LH secretion. Actions of progesterone • Has negative feedback effects on FSH and LH secretion during the luteal phase. • Maintains secretory activity of the uterus during the luteal phase. • Maintains pregnancy. • Raises the uterine threshold to contractile stimuli during pregnancy, i.e decreases sensitivity of 
the uterus to oxytocin. • Participates in the development of the breasts. • Increases body temperature • It stimulates respiration, and the alveolar PCO2 in women during the luteal phase of the 
menstrual cycle is lower than that in men. • Large doses of progesterone produce natriuresis, probably by blocking the action of aldosterone 
on the kidney.

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following is the most potent type of estrogen found in women of reproductive 
age group?
questions.explanation:
800 
Sold by @itachibot • Estradiol is the most abundant in the reproductive age group and is 12 and 80 times more 
potent than estrone and estriol respectively. • The principal sex steroids in females are estrogen, progestin, and androgen. Three estrogens are 
present in significant quantities—estradiol, estrone, and estriol.

questions.question: Question 23: Which is the predominant estrogen in the plasma of premenopausal non-pregnant women?
questions.explanation:
Estradiol is the predominant estrogen in the plasma of premenopausal non-pregnant women. It is 
primarily secreted from ovaries. Estrone is synthesized from dehydroepiandrosterone in adipose tissue stroma. Estrone is the 
abundant circulating form of estrogen in postmenopausal women. In pregnancy, the placenta uses dehydroepiandrosterone and its 16 alpha hydroxyl derivative to 
form large amounts of estrone and estriol.

questions.question:
Question 24: 788 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is false about estrogen action?

options.a: Development of secondary sexual characters in female

questions.explanation:
Estrogen does not stimulate osteoclast. Rather it prevents osteoporosis by inhibiting osteoclastic 
activity. Actions of Estrogen • Causes maturation and maintenance of the fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, and vagina. • Causes proliferation and development of ovarian granulosa cells. • Proliferation of endometrium • Causes the development of female secondary sex characteristics at puberty. • Maintains pregnancy. • Lowers the uterine threshold to contractile stimuli during pregnancy. • Causes the ductal development of the breasts. • Has both negative and positive feedback effects on FSH and LH secretion. • Up-regulates estrogen, LH, and progesterone receptors. • Increases secretion of angiotensinogen and thyroid binding globulin • Epiphyseal closure of long bones • Increase libido by acting on the hypothalamus. • Salt and water retention before menstruation • LDL cholesterol •  the local production of NOvasodilation • Inhibit osteoclast, prevent osteoporosis 801 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 25: A 12-year-old girl is undergoing pubertal changes. Her tanner stage is stage 4 for breast 
development and pubic hair scale. Which of the following pubertal changes is not due to 
estrogen?
questions.explanation:
Pubarche or development of axillary and pubic hair is not due to estrogen. It is due to testosterone 
(in both the sexes). Puberty in females : • Involves the beginning of menstrual cycles (menarche), breast development (thelarche), and an 
increase in adrenal androgen secretion (adrenarche). • Estradiol induces the development of secondary sex characteristics, including the breasts and 
reproductive tract, and increased fat in the hips. • Estrogens also regulate the growth spurt at puberty, vaginal cornification and cervical mucus 
production, induce closure of the epiphyses, have a positive effect in maintaining bone formation, 
and can antagonize the degrading actions of parathyroid hormone on bone.

questions.question: Question 26:  HCG is secreted by which of the following organs?
questions.explanation:
 HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) is secreted by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta. Some important features of  HCG: • hCG is a glycoprotein that contains galactose and hexosamine. • It is produced by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta. • It is made up of  and  subunits. • hCG- is identical to the  subunit of LH, FSH, and TSH. • hCG is primarily luteinizing and luteotropic and has little FSH activity. • Its presence in early pregnancy in urine is the basis of the various laboratory tests for pregnancy, 
and it can sometimes be detected in the urine as early as 14 days after conception.

questions.question: Question 27: Progesterone has how many carbon atoms?
questions.explanation: Progesterone has 21 carbon atoms.

questions.question:
Question 28: 789 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is false about milk ejection?

options.a: The neuroendocrine part of anterior pituitary is involved.
options.b: Its secretion occurs by contraction of lactiferous sinus.

questions.explanation:
The neuroendocrine part of the anterior pituitary is not involved in milk ejection. The posterior 
pituitary is involved in milk ejection reflex. The posterior pituitary secretes oxytocin, which is responsible for milk ejection. The anterior 
pituitary produces prolactin, which is responsible for lactogenesis. 802 
Sold by @itachibot Figure: Milk Ejection Reflex

questions.question: Question 29: Which of the following hormones is responsible for milk ejection?
questions.explanation:
• Oxytocin causes contraction of the myoepithelial cells lining the mammary ducts and ejects milk 
during suckling. But, it has no galactogenic effect. • Prolactin is responsible for milk secretion. • Estrogens are primarily responsible for the proliferation of the mammary ducts and the 
progesterone for the development of lobules.

questions.question: Question 30: Which of the following is not a function of oxytocin?
questions.explanation:
803 
Sold by @itachibot Lactogenesis is not a function of oxytocin. It is caused by prolactin. 804 
Sold by @itachibot Exercise Physiology
